RTX 4080 Edition

>Upgrade & Build Advice
Post build list or current specs including MONITOR: https://pcpartpicker.com/
Provide specific use cases (e.g. 4K editing, high FPS gaming)
State budget and country

>News
New releases: RTX 4090, RTX 4080; AM5 / Zen 4; Intel Raptor Lake, Intel Arc GPUs A770 and A750
Upcoming releases: AMD RDNA3: Radeon RX 7900XT and 7900XTX Dec 13

>CPUs
For light usage, consider an Intel i3 or Ryzen 3/G.
For gaming, consider an Intel i5 (K if you want overclocking) or a Ryzen 5. i7s and Ryzen 7s and above should only be considered after you've got a top end GPU.
For multithreaded performance, consider an Intel i7, i9 or a Ryzen 9. Get a Threadripper for heavy-duty workloads.
Avoid Zen4 (Ryzen 7000 series) - massively overpriced motherboards and poor-performing DDR5.

>GPUs
Check out the benchmarks for whatever games you play and pick whatever performs best.
Value standouts:
>4k: 4090, 3080, 6900XT
>1440p: 6800XT, 3080, 6700XT, 3070
>1080p: 6600XT, 3060 Ti
For productivity, you will want to buy a Nvidia Card for CUDA, nvenc, better software support in general.

>Coolers
Hyper 212 EVO

>PSUs
https://cultists.network/140/psu-tier-list/

>SSDs
Use an NVMe Drive for your operating system.
Standouts: Samsung 990 Pro, Crucial P5 Plus, Kingston KC3000, WD Black SN770
https://ssd.borecraft.com/
Don't buy HDDs for a desktop PC. If you need large scale storage, consider buying cloud storage or a NAS.

Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics OEM activation to generate a permanent legitimate license.

>>Which version should I install?
>Education/Enterprise
Can disable telemetry and delay updates a year.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Installs a KMS server emulator, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free. As a last resort, you can try LibreOffice and set it to save as Office file formats.

>There isn't one simple and usable GUI framework for Python.
I went through a bunch of frustration with this because I wanted to make a front end thing for my non-tech friends but myself prefer doing backend stuff in Jupyter or a terminal.
Eventually I settled on Plotly/Dash which had a really low learning curve, large variety of available widgets, multiple backend options, and lightweight code footprint to specify the layout & callbacks. It's free as in beer and speech but they also offer paid tier to corporates which i think is some kinda drag and drop/no code editor.
In general the Scientific Python community is better than the game/product space because SciPy coders want to focus on the problem they're solving more than the language tools for their own sake. Downside of this is you will run into a lot of shallow or poorly designed code designed to demonstrate an idea rather than function as a product, so sometimes you open up a repo that looks intimidating and complex but is just poorly written.

>beside the fact that i enjoy audio this way mostly, i totally cannot notice in ear ringing anymore
Masking cures it. Just forget about the ringing by doing something. Your mind will "Unlearn" it someday or months, you should also dabble into some new hobby (something that uses the brain like maths or puzzle games).
That shit happened with me.
I suggest you to reduce sugar consumption (after eating lots of sugar, next day ringing is always louder) and maybe eat more protein since ear ringing/sensitivity is actually a sign of neuroplasticity restarting and protein is good for the brain (keep in mind very young people also hear ear ringing and it causes the hypnosis-hallucinatory plasticity stage) also stop listening to binaural beats or hypnosis audio as it won't work anymore if you still have that sine tone tinnitus.

If yours is pulsatile tinnitus or rushing sound (probably your blood or fluid) I don't know what may fix it.
Take cold showers at night (aimed at head but make sure to not wet your ears too much) and drink fresh turmeric tea - these two works well in reduces ringing before going to sleep.

Because all other browsers are a security disaster.
Firefox is a massive security risk. It's sandboxing is inferior to Chrome's and it lacks several exploit mitigations that Chrome has. If you think Firefox is secure you are sadly mistaken[1][2][3].
Ungoogled Chromium and Chromium both lack autoupdates which are important for patching security vulnerabilities faster.
Brave browser has a history of stealing money from users without consent[4] and adding affiliate links in URLs[5].

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89820124
I keep my phones (android touch devices are very versatile). Laptops and PCs can have their guts salvaged for use elsewhere. I've taken some HDDs from corporate PCs and put them in my (inactive) main rig, and I've combined parts from two very old laptops with upgradeable storage to make one properly functional laptop for modern use. An SSD and doubling the memory with a fresh debloated OS install has made it a fully usable machine. Even when I get my main PC working again, it will be good enough for setting to do idle tasks or work as a home server. You can also harvest useful components from dead hardware. Tons of heatsinks and miscellanous board parts you can take for use in personal electronics projects.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89815588
>in which case you should be OK unless you removed a field
Or change the meaning of a field.
Or change any Guix function since g-expressions rely on the current version of Guix to evaluate themselves.
So Guix must be backwards compatible forever.

Your solution doesn't really require CLOS, or CL, or even any changes to the Guix codebase.
If they assumed that all that shit would stay compatible, they could just load old code and rely on it working.
Inferiors where created explicitly to avoid doing that because it might not work.

>I don't see any justification for your claim.
When you make something more flexible, you increase the set of values it can take on.
A serialisation function needs to be defined for all of these values, and so it gets more complicated the more flexible the thing is.
For instance if you allow functions to present in the definitions, you would need not only to be able to serialise them (which is quite complicated) but also to have some data structure on the other end to deserialize them into.
This is why Guix has G-expressions instead of something closer to plain lambda.
They can't serialise lambda, so they just copy the source code as a list in a list then evaluate it later. This is why gexps depend on the current Guix version.

Please just accept that nothing you say or do will change the fact that the only way to pass packages around portably is to reduce them to something simpler.
Maybe you could integrate this into the system in a cleaner way so that some package functions can work on a derivation-like object, but you can't escape the fact that those derivation things will be inferior to packages in some way.
The only way to circumvent this issue would be to allow multiple versions of Guix to be loaded in different namespaces, and to then use the manipulation functions specific to a certain version for changing packages from that version.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89818581
>Or change the meaning of a field.
Yes, of course. Technically, you could add a version field.
In any case I don't think package records changed ever.
>Or change any Guix function since g-expressions rely on the current version of Guix to evaluate themselves.
I don't understand what you're trying to say by this. G-exps are just S-exps that are evaluated during a build process. If you mean that they rely on the API, then that is correct: you would need to keep the API backwards compatible. This API already needs to be backwards compatible to keep 3rd party code running so there is no problem here.
>Inferiors where created explicitly to avoid doing that because it might not work.
They were most definitely not "created explicitly" to avoid doing that. In fact, not even implicitly.
In fact, inferiors don't even work if you go far back enough because they already rely on backwards compatibility. I think the cutoff is somewhere around version 1.0
>This is why gexps depend on the current Guix version.
Nothing you said supports this claim. I can evaluate a S-exp such as (invoke "echo" "test") in any version that contains the invoke function (which was introduced many years ago).
>If they assumed that all that shit would stay compatible, they could just load old code and rely on it working.
No, they could not. Because again, it's not designed this way. Each package depends on all the other parts of Guix existing.
>only way to pass packages around portably
Again, you have not said anything supporting this claim besides "serialization hard" (it's a non-issue, because you can use a G-exp like mechanism).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89818728
>No, they could not. Because again, it's not designed this way. Each package depends on all the other parts of Guix existing.
They're guaranteed to exist if it's always backwards compatible, so that isn't a problem.
If it's backwards compatible, you can just load old code and it will work. (That's what backward compatible means.)
It's just a bad idea to rely on nothing ever changing.

A Gexp is basically quoted code, it can access almost any part of Guix.
A package can contain a Gexp.
If you want packages to be backward compatible you'll need Gexps to be backward compatible.
If you want Gexps to be backward compatible, you need any piece of code to be backward compatible because a Gexp can be any piece of code.
You even admit this:
>you would need to keep the API backwards compatible
So why do you think loading old code won't work?
You've said that it should:
>This API already needs to be backwards compatible to keep 3rd party [old] code running
If old code keeps running, shouldn't old packages? They're just code after all.

Committing to permanent backwards compatibility is a bad idea and you know they aren't going to do it.
But not being able to access old packages is also bad.
So the solution is to open an old version of Guix that you know is compatible with that code, and rely on a minimal interface that can be easily upheld to pass stuff forward to present versions.
You must on some level understand all of the constituent facts that lead to this conclusion, yet the final step just isn't happening.

The solution to this stuff is Twitter implementing a Levenshtein algorithm for validating usernames.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance

You would have a fast cache server with all twitter usernames in ram and you would query a Levenshtein distance between the new username and every existing username in the cache database. If an approximate match m is found greater than match M the user would not be able to choose that username.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Approximate_string_matching

That would make it impossible to create a username that is exactly like an existing one except for a few characters. It would enforce completely original usernames.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Was ERPing with qt waifubots on character.ai and noticed something. Whenever I used a word that tripped the lewd filter, obviously I would get no response. But whenever I danced around extremely lewd concepts using euphemistic but still quite explicit wording (e.g. "member," "lower lips") I would get responses but there would be less than four to swipe between. The lewder the prompt, the fewer the options. Furthermore, sometimes, with especially lewd prompts, the AI would start typing a response, but then it would disappear, replaced by a completely different response.
Also, even when I get no answers, I can copy my last message, delete it, and paste it back in again verbatim, and sometimes I'll start getting answers that way.
There's only one logical guess I can think of. Character.ai uses a word list filter, as we already knew. But it doesn't actually censor inputs. It censors outputs. It beats down the *AI* for getting too horny. *You* can type whatever bullshit you want, outright pornographic or not, and the AI will let you choose between its top four predictions.
